results.title: Waiting to laugh
results.creator_credit: Hamid Naemi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Now settled in Australia, Afghani born Hamid reflects on the difficult and lonely times he and his sister experienced when they moved to Iran after their mother’s unexpected disappearance and their father’s death one year later.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hamid Naemi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Different type of game
results.creator_credit: Stephen Hodges, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The games men play - how cricket and the Aussie male ethos played a major part in Stephen’s adolescent years and on into his adult life. He learnt to play the game and the game never dies.

results.title: About my dad
results.creator_credit: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. But his family connections were to prove too dangerous and Huong eventually escaped by boat and made his way to Australia where he is now living with his wife and three sons. He dedicates this story to his father.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. results.title: [Remix: ACMI Collection 2]
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to the gems in the ACMI Collection. A remix of home movies and short works from the collection featuring elements on ‘how a movie is made’ and a split screen collage of moving images, interspersed with intertitles. The work was initially designed as part of a fundraising campaign.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Australian Dried Fruits Association; John Richardson; Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Ivan Gaal; Wine Australia and Tony Agapitos.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This short film shows scenes of the Royal Botanic Gardens and the Sydney Harbour Bridge in New South Wales.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:25:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge in the background
00:01:13:00 Sydney city streets

results.title: [Remix: Strike A Pose]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to people posing for the camera. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring families, fashion models and even a dog, all striking a pose for the camera. On a fashion catwalk, in a parade, on a photoshoot, in a factory or outdoor setting or just the back yard, fashionistas and family folk put their best foot forward from the 1940s to 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Dried Fruits Australia, Karen Wootton, Elenor Peach, Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office, Jenny & Owen Peake, Tony Agapitos and Ivan Gaal.

results.title: [Remix: Hats]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to hats and how we wear them. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring styles, shapes and fabrics of hats. Whether at the beach, riding a horse, driving a racing car or going for a swim, a fashionable head-covering is a must. Australian fashion’s best styles of hats for men, women and children from the 1930s to the 1980s are shown.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tony Agapitos, Karen Wootton, The Gadsden Family, Elenor Peach, Karen Corry, Jenny & Owen Peake, Gil Brealey & Paul Olson and John Richardson.

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film contains family gatherings for birthdays and weddings as well as Christmas in 1979, a picnic in the Eastern Gardens in Geelong, a trip to Cairns and a tennis tournament in Launceston, Tasmania. There are several gatherings for family birthdays, one of which is Dorothy Nixon’s 50th celebrations.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 extended family members enjoying a buffet meal at one of the family’s homes
00:00:55:00 family members pose for the camera in a backyard
00:01:36:00 extended family members at a long lunch table
00:02:23:00 arrivals to and/or departures from a family gathering
00:03:28:00 family members at the beach
00:03:43:00 the camera catches family members taking photos of a family gathering
00:04:24:00 filming the photographer
00:04:38:00 Stuart, with a mouth full of braces, grinning at the camera in his school uniform
00:04:49:00 Karen, Stuart and Les in their tennis gear
00:05:06:00 Dorothy in bed with Stuart and Karen visiting
00:05:18:00 a Labrador puppy eating in a garden
00:05:42:00 one of the family infants pretends to drink from a beer bottle at a family gathering
00:06:32:00 Les caught on camera at a sunny family picnic or barbeque gathering
00:07:30:00 shorts and long socks: a 1970s fashion look
00:07:57:00 at the barbeque
00:08:33:00 a family birthday party
00:09:30:00 views around the Nixon family home
00:09:58:00 birthday party inside the house
00:11:13:00 the extended family picnicking in a park
00:12:38:00 the 1970s three legged barbeque
00:12:52:00 feeding bread to the seagulls
00:13:50:00 views of the large family picnic including a 1960s green picnic case
00:14:50:00 views of children at the family picnic in the park
00:15:51:00 playing cricket at the picnic
00:16:44:00 looking out over scenery to some mountains
00:17:25:00 Dorothy walking by a palm tree in a lush park followed by a waterfall
00:18:06:00 filming from a train travelling through mountainous green countryside including waterfalls
00:18:45:00 arriving at Kuranda Rail Station in north Queensland.
00:18:53:00 views of orchids at the ‘Tropical Orchid Gardens at Beautiful Tinaroo’
00:20:52:00 waterbirds
00:21:12:00 ‘Ben Cropp’s Shipwreck Museum’
00:21:24:00 boats along a pier
00:21:31:00 feeding – and teasing – a crocodile for a rapt audience at an animal park
00:22:26:00 up close to some cassowaries at an animal park
00:23:50:00 a yellow sightseeing vessel sitting at the pier followed by views of the ocean floor through the glass bottom of the boat
00:25:11:00 a sandy shallow beach
00:25:40:00 Dorothy sitting on a rocky beach and in close up
00:25:54:00 a crocodile and some sharks in separate small enclosures
00:26:05:00 a motel swimming pool setting
00:26:35:00 motor boating down a river
00:27:40:00 fields under cultivation and a tourist bus
00:27:53:00 a rocky cascading river
00:27:59:00 a view looking across the wing of a ‘Qantas VH-TJO Lorikeet’ airplane
00:28:09:00 teenage Stuart in the backyard at home and with Dorothy
00:28:26:00 Stuart being camera shy in an airport waiting room
00:29:13:00 ‘Ansett VH-RMO Boeing 727’ airplane taking off

00:14:50:00 views of children at the family picnic in the park
00:15:51:00 playing cricket at the picnic
00:16:44:00 looking out over scenery to some mountains
00:17:25:00 Dorothy walking by a palm tree in a lush park followed by a waterfall
00:18:06:00 filming from a train travelling through mountainous green countryside including waterfalls

00:18:53:00 views of orchids at the ‘Tropical Orchid Gardens at Beautiful Tinaroo’

00:25:11:00 a sandy shallow beach

00:25:54:00 a crocodile and some sharks in separate small enclosures

00:28:26:00 Stuart being camera shy in an airport waiting room
00:29:13:00 ‘Ansett VH-RMO Boeing 727’ airplane taking off
description_for_label:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film contains family gatherings for birthdays and weddings as well as Christmas in 1979, a picnic in the Eastern Gardens in Geelong, a trip to Cairns and a tennis tournament in Launceston, Tasmania. There are several gatherings for family birthdays, one of which is Dorothy Nixon’s 50th celebrations.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 extended family members enjoying a buffet meal at one of the family’s homes
00:00:55:00 family members pose for the camera in a backyard
00:01:36:00 extended family members at a long lunch table
00:02:23:00 arrivals to and/or departures from a family gathering

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughte. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia, with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures a roadtrip to South Australia showing several ports and towns and the landscapes and ocean views along the way.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 title card ‘Exploring South Australia’ using a Shell (Gas and Oil) roadmap of SA
00:00:22:00 the Balmera Post Office with signs reading ‘Post and Telegraph Office’ and ‘Money Order and Commonwealth Savings Bank’
00:00:31:00 a town street with a large truck loaded with full hessian sacks followed by views of roses in the median strip gardens
00:01:32:00 Mrs Rankine holds some very large grapefruit
00:02:10:00 the travellers enjoy some public gardens
00:02:00:00 a ‘To Adelaide’ road sign on a flooded road, alongside some boats
00:03:20:00 filming from a punt that takes the travellers and cars across a waterway
00:05:00:00 sign reading ‘Port Augusta: Change here for Quorn Alice Springs’ followed by views of the rail station
00:05:20:00 street scenes with pedestrians, cars and buses
00:05:35:00 a long pipeline travels alongside a road in which Mrs Rankine, in a wonderful navy blue suit, sunglasses and cream ‘Maryjane’ style shoes, stands by the car taking in the views followed by two travellers on a motorcycle (motorbike)
00:06:13:00 the Whyalla Post Office followed by quiet street scenes including motorists and motorbike riders, an Orlando Wines advertising sign, lovely older buildings such as the Hotel Spencer and a great example of a 1940s or 1950s style small truck parked outside.
00:06:45:00 Mrs Rankine stands on a balcony of the hotel
00:06:57:00 a steam train carrying what appears to be aggregate crushed rock for road construction comes into view and shortly after, workers release the load into trackside rock and gravel piles, a fisherman and his bike on the pier and the rock being loaded onto the ship by way of a conveyor belt system
00:08:58:00 Mrs Rankine sits atop a very large pipeline, fanning flies away from her face
00:09:28:00 lengthy views of industrial works and cargo loading facilities
00:11:51:00 a lone blue-tongue lizard
00:12:18:00 the family car sits on top of a rise overlooking grassland and the sea, a ship, a town and in the foreground, an unusually low electricity pole and wiring
00:13:05:00 a ‘Port Lincoln’ sign on a building followed by scenes of the town, the bays, bobbing boats, public flowerbeds and 1940s and 1950s style cars, trucks and houses
00:14:53:00 the Pier Hotel with Mrs Rankine on a balcony and then in a window knitting with the blue and green sea in the background
00:15:15:00 scenes around the foreshore, out over the water, yachts, small boats and jettys and grassy shorelines
00:16:20:00 Mrs Rankine on shore in the blustery winds
00:16:55:00 a rail crossing on a sandy road with a ‘Commonwealth Roads’ sign warning of a ‘£50 penalty’
00:17:27:00 a wonderful ageing and long pier with a lighthouse at the end
00:17:42:00 a building bearing the name Port Pirie followed by views of the town and port, including a tugboat pulling a large ship into dock
00:18:15:00 another ship, named Pioneer Reef New York
00:18:18:00 a closer view of one of the tugboats followed by the Rankine family car parked on a dusty road
00:18:40:00 four big draught horses pulling a plough and then seven pulling a cultivator
00:19:07:00 Port Broughton Post Office with a sign for the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and then the Hotel Broughton
00:19:25:00 Mrs Rankine sits on a seat outside the hotel in front of a stained glass window sign for the ‘Parlor’ (interestingly, the American version of spelling), which would have been the hotel’s ladies parlour when women were not allowed in the public bar of a hotel
00:19:44:00 the Point Broughton War Memorial
00:19:58:00 a friend with their cat
00:20:05:00 a roadsign for Port Victoria followed by son-in-law Bob Wootten and grandson on a pier, who then join Mrs Rankine and Bettye (Rankine) Wootten
00:20:55:00 sign for Kadina flashes by and a train carriage, named ‘Pelican’ which was part of the ‘Bluebird Railcars’ that travelled around South Australia at the time; passengers board the carriage while luggage is loaded from a truck parked alongside
00:21:29:00 Kenneth’s grandson in his stroller and some quick scenes around the town
